sleep_day <- read.csv("C:/Users/maria/OneDrive/Desktop/Google Capstone Project - Case Study 2/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/sleepDay_merged.csv")
weight_log <- read.csv("C:/Users/maria/OneDrive/Desktop/Google Capstone Project - Case Study 2/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/weightLogInfo_merged.csv")
source.946f35dd:
We can see that the daily activities include most of the important variables, except the weight and sleep data.Note that all 3 datasets have the 'Id' field. This could be used to merge them later. 

Also, the sleep and weight data have the date & time combined whereas the daily activities includes only the date. We can transform them to improve analysis when comparing these topics later.
source.f8910e35:
# Find any duplicates
sum(duplicated(daily_activity))

# Find any missing values
sum(is.na(daily_activity))

# Rename ActivityDate column to Date
colnames(daily_activity)[colnames(daily_activity) == "ActivityDate"] <- "Date"

# Transform date type
daily_activity$Date <-  as.Date(daily_activity$Date,format='%m/%d/%Y')

# Add new column for weekdays
daily_activity$Weekdays<- wday(daily_activity$Date, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE)

# Add a new column with the total active minutes
daily_activity2 <- daily_activity %>% 
  mutate(TotalActiveMinutes = VeryActiveMinutes + FairlyActiveMinutes + LightlyActiveMinutes)

# Check to see if changes have been made to new table
str(daily_activity2)
source.83358ca8:

# Transform date type
sleep_day$Date <-  as.Date(sleep_day$Date,format='%m/%d/%Y')

# Add new column for weekdays
sleep_day$Weekdays<- wday(sleep_day$Date, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE)

# Check to see if changes have been made
str(sleep_day)
source.3e7dab36:
number_of_logs <- daily_activity2 %>% 
  count(Id) %>% 
  arrange(n)


ggplot(number_of_logs, aes(x=Id, y=n)) + 
  geom_point()+
  ggtitle("Number of Daily Entries by User Id")+
  labs(x="Unique ID", y="Number of daily entries")+
  geom_hline(yintercept = 21, linetype="longdash", color="red")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=12), text = element_text(size=10))

source.ce02a20e:
log_type <- c("Daily activity records","Daily sleep records")
log_number <-c(n_distinct(daily_activity2$Id),n_distinct(sleep_day$Id))
log_count <- data.frame(log_type,log_number)

ggplot(log_count, aes(log_type,log_number)) +
  geom_bar(stat= "identity", fill="pink")+ 
  geom_text(aes(label=log_number), vjust=4, color="black")+
  labs(title="Total Records by Types",  x= "Record Types", y="Number of Records")

ggplot(sleep_day, aes(x=TotalMinutesAsleep)) + 
  geom_histogram(aes(y=..density..), binwidth=50,alpha=0.2)+
  geom_density(alpha=0.5, fill="#FF6666") +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mean(TotalMinutesAsleep, na.rm=T)), color="black", linetype="dashed")+
  labs(title="Total Minutes Asleep", x= "Total Minutes Asleep", y="Density")

ggplot(daily_activity2, aes(x = TotalActiveMinutes, y = Calories))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_smooth()+
  labs(title="Daily Activity vs. Calories Burned", x= " Active Minutes", y="Calories Burned")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=12), text = element_text(size=10))
source.70d869fe:
average_very_active_minutes <- daily_activity2 %>% 
  group_by(Weekdays) %>% 
  summarise_at(vars(VeryActiveMinutes),
               list(VeryActiveMinutes = mean))

ggplot(average_very_active_minutes, aes(x=Weekdays,y=VeryActiveMinutes, group=1))+
  geom_line(color = "black")+
  labs(title="Average Very Active Minutes by Weekdays", x= "Weekdays", y="Daily Very Active Minutes")+
  geom_text(aes(label=round(VeryActiveMinutes, digits=0), hjust=-0.75, vjust=0.75),size=3)+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=14), text = element_text(size=10), axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, hjust=1))

source.bed630fd:
The daily activity has 33 distinct participants which means everyone is included. However, the sleep data has 24 and the weight data has 8. The weight information for most participants is missing, therefore the best option would be to stop using this data as it will affect the analysis. This can be seen further with the observations, with the weight data including only 67.

Note that the rest of the analysis excludes the weight log information.

##### Cleaning and manipulation of data

Daily activity:
1. Remove any missing values
2. Remove duplicates 
3. Rename the ActivityDate column to Date
4. Change the Date column from character type to date 
5. Create a new column to represent days of the week called Weekdays
6. Create a new column with the sum of active minutes called TotalActiveMinutes
source.9c5d73a5: 6.Mondays and Tuesdays are the most active days, while Thursday and Sunday are the most inactive.
source.9fc6d49c: ##### Quick summary of the clean data
source.d573aca2:
# Bellabeat Case Study

#### 1. ASK

##### About Bellabeat

Bellabeat is a successful small high-tech company that manufactures health-focused smart products. Collecting data on activity, sleep, stress and reproductive health has allowed Bellabeat to empower women with knowledge about their own health and habits. Since it was founded in 2013, Bellabeat has grown rapidly and quickly positioned itself as a tech-driven wellness company for women.

##### Primary stakeholders:

Urska Srsen - Bellabeat's cofounder and Chief Creative Officer

Sando Mur - Mathematician and Bellabeat's cofounder

##### Secondary stakeholders:

Bellabeat marketing analytics team - A team of data analysts responsible for collecting, analyzing and reporting data that helps guide Bellabeat's marketing strategy.

##### Business task:

Analyze smart devise usage data in order to gain insight into how consumers use non-Bellabeat smart devices. Select one product to apply these insights to:

1. What are some trends in smart device usage?
2. How could these trends apply to Bellabeat customers?
3. How could these trends help influence Bellabeat marketing strategy?

#### 2. PREPARE

##### Data sources used:

1. https://www.kaggle.com/arashnic/fitbit (CC0: Public Domain, dataset made available through Mobius)
2. Kaggle data set - Thirty eligible Fitbit users consented to the submission of personal tracker data, including minute-level output for physicial activity, heart rate, and sleep monitoring. It includes information about daily activity, steps, and heart rate that can be used to explore users' habits.
source.e72356e4:
#### 3. PROCESS

##### Installing and loading common packages and libraries
source.e959726c:
Overall, this shows that participants start off their week with alot of energy but the pace slows down mid week. This could vary depending on the different jobs, schedules, lifestyles they have. Also, it slowly picks up again on Friday which could be motivated by activities etc.

#### 5. SHARE

What are some of high level trends?
1. Participants used their fitness trackers for daily activity the most.
2. Participants are less active towards the end of the work week.
3. Participants spend over half of the day inactive.

#### 6. ACT

How could these trends help?

1. Auto capturing feature for sleep trackers
A further investigation into why participants dont log their sleep activity. Adding reminders to go log their sleep and capturing it automatically would make things easier. Also, maybe promote a healthy mindulfness sleep routine to entice users.

2. Promote regular excercise
Towards the end of the week, people become more inactive. Adding short reminders or workout videos to Bellabeat's app could inspire users to stay active during the week.

3. Just do it!
Too much time is spent inactive. Adding regular reminders of all sorts during the active hours of the day could significantly trigger changes.Make use of the smart devices that in close contact with the skin, maybe introduce light vibrations as regular reminders.

Thank you,

Mariam Sengo
source.1a476a9d:
#### 4. ANALYSIS

1. Consumers use smart devices to record their daily activities the most. Only 24 people recorded their sleep activity. I believe it is common for people to not always record their daily sleep because of different reasons such as comfort.I would suggest in looking for a much more comfortable design or a different location on the body e.g around the ankle, headband etc

source.906e3a21:
##### Loading CSV files

I selected 3 datasets that I believe aligned with the business objectives. They provide the daily activity, sleep times and weight log information. I also renamed them to make them easier to work with.

Here, I will create dataframes and read in the selected CSV files from the dataset.
